publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: as you are a great admirer of poetry especially the politer sort, and whereas I here have a piece supposed to be done by dean Swift a greater genius than \del·whose\ which perhaps never appeard on the Stage of action, which is one of the most \del·pieces\ witty pieces you seldom \meet·over·met\ with, & because its so rare a Book that but two of them ever Came to this province, being in great measure prevented by Wallpole against whom the plan of the poem is levell'd, mine also being in manuscript, I shall take the trouble I should say pleasure to give you the whole piece in this Letter
I am Sir with profound Esteem & humble Prostration──
<«MDBU»>Your most faithfull friend</«MDBU»>
<«MDBU»>&</«MDBU»>

<«MDBU»>Humble Servt<«MDBU»> 08.</«MDBU»></«MDBU»>
Will Livingston.
All human Race would fain be witts
and Millions miss, for one that hitts,
Youngs universal passion, Pride
Was never known to spread so wide,
Say Britain could you ever boast;
Three Poets in an Age at most,
Our chilling Climate hardly bears
A Sprig of bays in fifty years
while Eve'ry fool his Claim alledges
As if it grew in Common hedges.
what reason can there be assign'd
For this perversness in the mind?
Brutes find out where their Talents lie
A Bear will not attempt to fly.
A founderd horse will oft debate
Before he tryes a five barr'd Gate.
A dog by Instinct turns aside
Who sees the ditch too deep & wide.
But Man we find the only Creature
Who led by folly fights with nature
Who when she loudly cryes forbare
With Obstinacy fixes there,
& where his Genius least inclines,
Absurdly bends his whole designs,
Not Empire, to the rising Sun,
By valour, Conduct, fortune, won,
Nor highest wisdom in debates
For framing Laws to Govern States
Nor Skill in Sciences profound
So large to grasp the Circle round
Such heavenly Influence require
As how to strike the Muses Lyre.
Not Beggars bred on bulk begot
Nor Bastard of a Pedlar Schot
Nor Boy brought up to Cleaning Shoes
The Spawn of Bridewell or the Stewes,
Nor Infants dropt the Spurious pledges
of Gypsies littring under hedges
Are so disqualify'd by Fate
To rise in Church or law or State
As he whom Phoebus in his ire
Hath blasted with Poetick Fire
what hope of Custom in the Fair
While not a Soul demands your ware,
Where you have nothing to produce
For private or for publick use,
Court City Country want you not
You cannot bribe betray or plot
For Poets law makes no provision
The wealthy have you in derision
Of State affairs you Cannot Smatter
Are awkard when you try to flatter
Your Portion taking Britain round
Was just one annual hundred pound
Now not so much as in remainder
Since Cibber brought in an Attainder
For ever fixt by right divine
(A monarchs right) on Grubstreet Line
Poor Starving bard how Small thy gains
How unproportiond to thy pains,
And here a Simile comes pat in
Tho' Chickens take a month to fatten
The Guests in less than half an hour
Will more than half a schore devour,
So after toiling twenty days
To earn a Stock of pence & praise
Thy Labours grown to Criticks prey
Are Swallow'd ore a dish of tea,
Gone to be never heard of more
Gone where the Chickens went before.
How shall a new attempter learn
Of different Spirits to disern,
And how distinguish which is which
The Poets vein or Scribbling itch,
Then hear an old Experienc'd Sinner
Instructing thus a young beginner.
Consult yourself & if you find
A powerfull Impulse urge your mind
Impartial Judge within your breast
What Subject you Can manage best,
Whether your Genious most inclines,
To Satyr, praise, or hum'rous lines,
To Elegies in mourfull Tone
Or prologue sent from hand unknown,
Then rising with Aurora's light
The Muse invok'd──sitt down to write,
Blot out insert, Correct, refine,
E overInlarge, diminish, interline
Be mindfull when Invention fails
To scrath your head, & bite your nails,
Your Poem finish next your Care
Is needfull to transcribe it fair
In Modern wit all printed Thrash is
Set off with numrous breaks & dashes.
To States·men would you give a wipe
You print (inserted·it) in Italick type
When Letters are in Vulgar Shapes
Its ten to one the witt Eschapes,
But when in Capitals Exprest,
the dullest reader smokes the jest
Or else perhaps he may invent
A better than the poet meant
As learn'd Commentators veiw
In Homer more than homer knew.
Your Poem in your modish dress
Correctly fitted for the press,
Convey by penny Post to Lintot,
But let no friend alive look int'ot
If Lintot thinks twill quit the cost
You need not fear your labour lost
And how agreably Surprized
Are you to see it advertized.
The Hawker shews you one in print
As fresh as farthings from the mint
The product of your toil & sweathing
A Bastard of your own begetting.
Be sure at Wills the following day
Lie snug & hear what Criticks say
And if you find the general vouge
Pronounces you a Stupid rouge
Damns all your thoughts as low & little
Sitt still & swallow down your spittle
Be Silent as a Polititian
For talking may begat Suspicion
Or praise the Judgement of yẹ town
And help your·self to run it down
Give up your fond paternal pride.
Nor argue on the weaker Side
For poems read without a Name
We justly praise or justly blame
And Criticks have no partial vews
Except they know whom they abuse
And since you ne'er provok'd the Spite,
Depend upon't their Judgements right
But if you blab, you are undone
Consider what a risque you run
You loose your Credit all at once
The Town will mark you for a dunce
The vilest doggrel Grubstreet Sends
will pass for yours with foes & friends
and you must bear the whole disgrace
Till some fresh blockhead takes your place.
Your Secrets kept, your poems Sunk
and Sent in quires to line a trunk
If Still you be disposd to Rhime
Go try your hand a Second time
Again you fail, yet safe's the word
Take Courage & attempt a third,
But first with care employ your thoughs
where Criticks mark'd your former faults
The trivial turns, the borrow'd witt
The Similes that nothing fitt,
The Cant which evr'y fool repeats
Town-Jests and Coffee house Conceits
Descriptions, tedious, flat and dry
And introduc'd the Lord knows why
Or where we find the fury Set
Against the harmless Alphabet
On Aṣ & Bṣ your malice vent
while readers wonder whom you meant.
A Publick or a private Robber
A statesman or a South Sea Jobber
A prelate who no god believes
A ────or Den of Thieves
A pick purse on the bar or bench
A duchess or a Suburb wench
Or oft when Epithets you link
In gaping lines to fill a Chink
like Stepping Stones to save a Stride
In streets where kennels are too wide
Or like a heel piece to support
A Cripple with one foot too Short
Or like a Bridge that joyns a marish
To moor-land of a diffrent parish
so have I seen ill Coupled hounds
drag diffrent ways in miry grounds
So Geographers in Afric maps
With Savage pictures fill their Gaps
And o'er Inhabitable downs
Place Elephants Instead of Towns.
But 'tho' you miss your third Essay
you need not throw your pen away
Lay now aside all thoughs of Fame
To spring more profitable game
From party Merit seek Support
The vilest verse thrives best at Court
A pamphlet in Sṛ Rob's Defence
will never fail to bring in pence
Nor be Concernd about the Sale
He pays his workman on the nail
A prince the moment he is crownd
Inherits evr'y virtue round
As Emblems of the Sovreign power
Like other bawbles of the Tower
Is genr'ous, valiant, just & wise
And so Continues till he dies
His humble Senate this professes
In all their Speeches, Votes, addresses
But once you fix him in a Tomb
His virtues fade his vices bloom
And each Perfection wrong Imputed
Is folly at his death Confuted,
The load of poems in his praise
Ascending make an fun'ral blaze
As soon as you can hear his Knell
This god on Earth turns devil in Hell
And lo his Ministers of State
Transform'd to Imps his Levee wait
Where in this Scene of endless woe
They ply their former arts below
And as they Sail in Charons boat
Contrive to bribe the Judges Vote
To Cerberus they give a Sop
His triple barking mouth to Stop
Or In the Ivr'y gate of Dreams
Project -·-·-·- and -·-·-·-
Or hire their party Pamplyteers
To set Elysium by the Ears.
Then Poet if you mean to thrive
Employ your Muse on kings alive
With prudence gathring up a Cluster
Of all the virtues you Can muster
Which form'd into a Garland Sweet
Lay humbly at your Monarch's feet
Who as the Odours reach his Throne
Will smile & think them all his own
For Law & Gosple both determine
All virtues lodge in Royall Ermine
(I mean the Oracles of both)
(Who shall depose it upon Oath)
Your Garland in the following Reign,
Change but their Names will do again.
But if you think this trade too base
(which seldom is the Dunce's Case)
Put on the Criticks brow & sitt
A Will's the puny Judge of witt
A nod, a Shrug, a Scornful smile
With Caution usd may serve a while
Proceed no farther in your part
Before you learn the terms of art
(For you may easy be too far gone
In all our modern Criticks Jargon
Then talk with more authentick face
Of Unities in time and Place,
Get Scraps of Horace from your friends
And have them at your fingers ends
Learn Aristotles Rules by Rote
And at all Hazards boldly Quote
Judicious Rhimer oft Reveiw
Wise Dennis, & profound Bossu
Read all the prefaces of Dryden
For these our Criticks much Confide in
(Tho' merely writt at first for filling
To raise the volumes price one Shilling)
A forward Critick often dupes us
With sham Quotations Peri Hupsous
And if we have not read Longinus
Will magisterially outshine us
That lest with greek he overrun ye
Procure the Book for love or monehole
Translated from Boileau's Traslhole
And quote quotation on Quotation
At Wills you hear a poem read
Where Battles from the Table head
Reclining on his Elbow Chair
Gives Judgement with decisesihole aihole
To whom the tribe of Circling wits
As to an Oracle Submitts
He gives direction to the Town
To cry it up or run it down
(Like Courtiers when they send a note
Instructing members how to vote)
He sitts the stamp of bad & good
Tho' not a word be understood.
Your lesson learn yowill be secure
To gett the Name of Connessure
And when your merits one be known
Procure Deciples of your own.
Our Poets you can never want them
Spread thro Augusta Trinobantum
Computing by their pecks of Coals
Amount to just Nine thousand Souls
These or'e their proper districts govern
Of witt & humour Judges Sovereign,
In evry street a City Bard
Rules like an Alderman his ward
His indisputed rights Contend
Thro all the Lane from end to end
The neighbours round admire his Shrewdness
for songs of Loyalty & Lewdness.
Outdone by none in Rhyming well
Altho' he never learnt to spell.
Two bordring witts Contend for Glory
and one is Wigg & one is Tory
And this for Epicks Claims the Bays
And that for Eligiak Lays,
So fam'd for Numbers soft & Smooth
By lovers Spoke in Punche's Booth
For lofty lines in Smithfield drolls
As justly fame Some men extolls
Bavius in wapping gains renown
And Maevius Reigns o're Kentish Town
Tigellus plac'd in Phoebus car
From Ludgate shines to Temple bar
Harmonious Cibber entertains
The Court with annual birth day Strains
Whence Gay was banishd in discrage
Where pope will never Show his face
Where Y---- Must torture his invention
To flatter knaves or lose his pension
But these are not a thousandst part
of Jobbers in the poet's art
Attending each his proper Station
And all in due Subordination
Thro' evry ally to be found
In Garrit high or under ground
And when the joyn their Pericranis
Out skips a Book of Miscellanies
Hobbs Clearly proves that evry Creature
Lies in a state of war by nature.
The greater from the smallest wath
But meddle seldom with their match.
A whale of moderate size will draw
A shole of Herrings down his maw
A fox with geese his belly crams
A wolf distroys a thousand Lambs
But search among the Rhyming race
The brave are worried by the base
If on parnassus top you sitt
You rarely bite, are always bitt
Each poet of Inferiour Size
on you shall rail & Criticize
And strive to tear you limb from Limb
While others do as much for him
The Vermin only teaze & pinch
Their foes superiour by an Inch
So Nuturallists observe a flea
Hath Smaller fleas that on him prey
And these have smaller fleas to bite them
And so proceeds ad Infinitum
Thus evry poet in his kind
Is bit by him that Comes behind
Who tho too little to be seen
Can teaze & gall & give the Spleen
Call dunces fools & Sons of whores
Lay Grubstreet on each others doors
Extoll his greek & Roman masters
And Curse our modern Poetasters
Complain as many an AnAntient bard did
How Genius is no more rewarded
How wrong a taste remains amongus
How much our ancestors outsung us
Can personate an awkard Scorn
for those who are not poets born
And all their brother dunces lash
Who croud the press with hourly thrah.
O Grubstreet how do I bemoan thee
Whose graceless Children scorn to own thee
Their filial piety forgott
Deny their Country like a Shot
Tho by their Idiom & grimace
they soon betray their native place
Yet thou hast greater cause to be
Asham'd of them than they of thee
Degenerate from their antient brood
Since first the Court allow'd them food
Remainds a Difficulty still
To purchase fame by writing ill
From Fleknoe down to Howards time
How few have reachd the low Sublime
For when our high-born Howard dy'd
Blackmore alone his place Supply'd
And least a Chasm should interveen
When death had finish'd Blackmores Reign
The leaden crown devol'd to thee
Great poet of the hollow Tree
But oh how unsecure thy Throne
A Thousand Bards thy Rights disown
They plot to turn in factious Zeal
Duncenia to a Common weal
And with rebellious arms pretend
An Equall priveledge to discend.
In Bulk there are not more degrees
from Elephants to mite in Cheese
Than what a Curious eye may trace
In Creatures of the Rhyming race
from bad to worse & worse they fall
But who can reach the worst of all
For tho' in Nature Depth & Height
Are equally held Infinite
In poetry the Height we know
Is only held Infinite below
For Jnstance when you rashly think
No Rhymer can like Welsted sink
His merits balanc'd you shall find
That Fielding leaves him far behind
Concennen more Aspiring bard,
Climbs downward deeper by a yard
Smart Jemmy More with vigour drops
The rest pursue as thick as hops
With heads to point the Gulf they enter
linkt perpendicular to the Center
And as their heels elated rise
Their Heads attempt the nether Skies.
O What Indignity for Shame
To prostitute the Muses Name
By flattring -·-·- whom Heaven designd
The plagues & Scourges of mankind
Bred up in Ignorance & Sloth
and evr'y vice that nurses both.
Fair Brittain, In thy Monarch blest
Whose virtues bear the strictest test
Whom never faction could bespatter
Nor minister nor poet flatter
What Justice in rewarding merit
What magnanimity of Spirit
What Lineaments divine we trace
Thro all the features of his face
Tho peace & olive bind his hands
Confest the Conquering Hero stands
Hydaspes Indus & the Ganges
Dread from his hand impending Changes
From him the Tartar & Chinese
Short by the knees intreat for peace.
The Consort of his Royal bed
A perfect goddess born & bred
Appointed Sovereign Judge to sitt
On learning Eloquence & witt
Our Eldest hope divine Iulus
(Late very late ô may he Rule us)
what early manhood hath he shown
Before his downy beard be grown
Think then what wonders will be done
By going on as he begun
An Heir for Brittain to secure
As long as Sun an moon endure,
The Remnant of the Royall blood
Comes pouring on me like a flood
Bright goddesses in Number five
Duke William Sweetest Prince alive.
Now sing the Minister of State
Who shines alone without a mate
Observe with what Majestick port
fadedhis Atlas stands to prop the Court
Intent the Publick debts to pay
fadedike prudent Fabius by delay,
Thou great Vicegerent of the King
Thy praises evry muse Shall Sing
In all affairs thou sole director
of witt and Learning Cheif protector
Thô small the time thou hast to spare
The Church is thy peculiar Care
Of pious Prelates what a Stock
You Chuse to rule the Sable flock
You raise the Honour of the Peerage
Proud to attend you at the Steerage
You dignify the noble race
Content your self with humbler place,
Now Learning valour virtue Sense
To titles have the Sole pretence
Sṭ George beheld the with delight
Vouchsafe to be an azure knight
when on thy breast & Sides Herculean
He fixt the Star & String Cerulean.
Say poet in what other Nation
Shone ever such a Constellation
Attend ye Popes & youngs & Gays
And tune your harps & strow your bays
Your Panegyricks here provide
You Cannot err on flattry's Side
Above the Stars exalt your Style
You still are low Ten Thousand mile,
On Lewis all his bards bestowd
of Incense many a Thousand Load
But Europe mortifyd his pride
And Swore the fawning Rascals ly'd
Yet what the world refus'd to Lewis
Apply'd to -·-·-·-·- exactly true is
Exactly true? Invidious poet
It's fifty thousand times below it.
Translate me now some lines if you can
From Virgil martial ovid Lucan
They could all pow'r in Heaven divide
And do no wrong on either Side
They'ill teach you how to split a hair
Give -------- & Jove an equall Share
Yet why should we be laid so streight
Pu give my ──────butter weight
And reason good, for many a year
──Never intermeddled here
Nor tho his Priests be duly paid
Did ever we desire his aid
We now can better do without him
Since Woolston gave us arms to rout him.
